title: Data from Local System
descrption: Sensitive data can be collected from local system sources, such as the file system or databases of information residing on the system prior to Exfiltration.Adversaries will often search the file system on computers they have compromised to find files of interest. They may do this using a Command-Line Interface, such as cmd, which has functionality to interact with the file system to gather information. Some adversaries may also use Automated Collection on the local system.
Platform: Linux, macOS, Windows, GCP, AWS, Azure
System Requirements: Privileges to access certain files and directories
Data Sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters

related.Name: APT1
related.Description: APT1 has collected files from a local victim.[44]

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: APT28 has retrieved internal documents from machines inside victim environments, including by using Forfiles to stage documents before.[5][52]

related.Name: APT3
related.Description: APT3 will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.[43]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 has collected data from victims' local systems.[42]

related.Name: BADNEWS
related.Description: When it first starts, BADNEWS crawls the victim's local drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.[15][16]

related.Name: BadPatch
related.Description: BadPatch collects files from the local system that have the following extensions, then prepares them for exfiltration: .xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .mdb, .rar, .zip, .doc, .docx.[29]

related.Name: Bankshot
related.Description: Bankshot collects files from the local system.[6]

related.Name: BRONZE BUTLER
related.Description: BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.[51]

related.Name: Calisto
related.Description: Calisto can collect data from user directories.[12]

related.Name: China Chopper
related.Description: China Chopper's server component can upload local files.[32][33][34]

related.Name: Cobalt Strike
related.Description: Cobalt Strike can collect data from a local system.[2]

related.Name: CosmicDuke
related.Description: CosmicDuke steals user files from local hard drives with file extensions that match a predefined list.[22]

related.Name: Dark Caracal
related.Description: Dark Caracal collected complete contents of the 'Pictures' folder from compromised Windows systems.[50]

related.Name: Dragonfly 2.0
related.Description: Dragonfly 2.0 collected data from local victim systems.[45]

related.Name: Dust Storm
related.Description: Dust Storm has used Android backdoors capable of exfiltrating specific files directly from the infected devices.[46]

related.Name: FLASHFLOOD
related.Description: FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system. FLASHFLOOD will scan the My Recent Documents, Desktop, Temporary Internet Files, and TEMP directories. FLASHFLOOD also collects information stored in the Windows Address Book.[21]

related.Name: Forfiles
related.Description: Forfiles can be used to act on (ex: copy, move, etc.) files/directories in a system during (ex: copy files into a staging area before).[5]

related.Name: GravityRAT
related.Description: GravityRAT steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.[18]

related.Name: Honeybee
related.Description: Honeybee collects data from the local victim system.[55]

related.Name: Hydraq
related.Description: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can read data from files.[23][24]

related.Name: Ixeshe
related.Description: Ixeshe can collect data from a local system.[37]

related.Name: Kazuar
related.Description: Kazuar uploads files from a specified directory to the C2 server.[26]

related.Name: Ke3chang
related.Description: Ke3chang gathered information and files from local directories for exfiltration.[40]

related.Name: Kimsuky
related.Description: Kimsuky has collected Office, PDF, and HWP documents from its victims.[59]

related.Name: Koadic
related.Description: Koadic can download files off the target system to send back to the server.[1]

related.Name: Lazarus Group
related.Description: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is uploaded to one of its 10 C2 servers. Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta copies specified directories from the victim's machine, then archives and encrypts the directories before uploading to its C2 server.[47][48][49]

related.Name: LightNeuron
related.Description: LightNeuron can collect files from a local system.[38]

related.Name: Linfo
related.Description: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can obtain data from local systems.[17]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete searches the File system for files of interest. [39]

related.Name: menuPass
related.Description: menuPass has collected various files from the compromised computers.[56]

related.Name: MobileOrder
related.Description: MobileOrder exfiltrates data collected from the victim mobile device.[13]

related.Name: njRAT
related.Description: njRAT can collect data from a local system.[35]

related.Name: Pasam
related.Description: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve files.[27]

related.Name: Patchwork
related.Description: Patchwork collected and exfiltrated files from the infected system.[54]

related.Name: PinchDuke
related.Description: PinchDuke collects user files from the compromised host based on predefined file extensions.[19]

related.Name: PoisonIvy
related.Description: PoisonIvy creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can steal system information.[25]

related.Name: PowerSploit
related.Description: PowerSploit contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can access data from local files, volumes, and processes.[3][4]

related.Name: POWERSTATS
related.Description: POWERSTATS can upload files from compromised hosts.[31]

related.Name: Proxysvc
related.Description: Proxysvc searches the local system and gathers data.[14]

related.Name: PUNCHTRACK
related.Description: PUNCHTRACK scrapes memory for properly formatted payment card data.[10][11]

related.Name: RawPOS
related.Description: RawPOS dumps memory from specific processes on a victim system, parses the dumped files, and scrapes them for credit card data.[7][8][9]

related.Name: Rover
related.Description: Rover searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.[30]

related.Name: Soft Cell
related.Description: Soft Cell collected data from the victim's local system, including password hashes from the SAM hive in the Registry.[58]

related.Name: Stealth Falcon
related.Description: Stealth Falcon malware gathers data from the local victim system.[41]

related.Name: Threat Group-3390
related.Description: Threat Group-3390 ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.[53]

related.Name: TrickBot
related.Description: TrickBot collects local files and information from the victim’s local machine.[28]

related.Name: Turla
related.Description: Turla RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.[57]

related.Name: Ursnif
related.Description: Ursnif has collected files from victim machines, including certificates and cookies.[36]

related.Name: yty
related.Description: yty collects files with the following extensions: .ppt, .pptx, .pdf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .docm, .rtf, .inp, .xlsm, .csv, .odt, .pps, .vcf and sends them back to the C2 server.[20]
